job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Samsung is famous. You may have a chance to get free Android devices. Although their base salary is relatively low comparing to the main stream American companies, their compensation is not bad and their base salary is still higher than many Asian companies, such as Foxconn, Huawei, Supermicro, or ASUS etc.
cons:
The base salary is relatively low. The management and company culture are notorious bad. They exploit employee to contribute patent to company. It counts into your half-year assessment which is the reference for your bonus. As I have mentioned, their base salary is low, but their bonus may not be bad. Their the manager controls substantial portion of your yearly income, and that will serve a great leverage for the manager to exploit the employee.

Another thing is that their company IT is notoriously poor. For example, my current American company outsources the IT architecture to professional IT service vendor (such as Citrix). When you got some trouble on your PC, all you need to do is to make a phone call to the help desk, and you quickly get a professional IT service to fix your computer. Nonetheless, in Samsung, fixing your own PC is a part of your skill in your work. You have to fix your own PC or you will be treated incompetence. The group which I worked for in Samsung does have a Korean IT guy. However, he acted like your boss. You have to beg him to fix your PC or your may have to wait for a long time, and you may not finish your job because of that. Your manager won't listen to your "excuse" saying that you could not finish your work on time because your PC has some issue. blah blah blah ...

cons:
I have Korean background, so I can talk about the actual issues. When I was there, and I am sure it will be the same, Korean employees from HQ are the problem. HQ is sending people to help local branches every 3 or 4 years, depending on their positions, but they won't respect local culture at all. They bring all bad Korean culture to work. Remember that managers in Korea HAVE TO be respected by employees. Managers are god. They can do whatever they want, and even humiliating you in public. This is what those people have. If you have Korean background, then good luck with that. If you don't have it, you will have less opportunities to get promoted. Yes, this is who they are. 

They prefer bi-lingual, because they can control employees badly. These Koreans don't have critical authority for hiring decision but they still do. Those Koreans love to get involved in anything and everything. During any meetings, if you don't get interrupted by them for 5 mins, then you are super lucky. They don't give you opportunities to speak at any meeting at all. I assume that they don't trust you in general. The best part of those Koreans is they are REALLY good at criticizing. They can find what your weakness is and what you did wrong. This is super easy for them. They have Phd for that. 

Korean culture has good and bad, and these people introduce all bad korean culture. Actually, HQ has much better culture based on what friends say. That's why Samsung Electronics reputation is higher on glassdoor than it should be. 

I still recommend it because work is rationally more than okay, and you can learn a lot. If you have ability to ignore their bad etiquettes and nagging, then you can work there. Good brand name on your resume too. Otherwise, you will get stress a lot.

job_title: Senior Product Manager in Suwŏn, Kyonggi
pros: Global reach. Mega brand which can get you a meeting with almost anyone. Chance to see/develop some cutting-edge new technologies if you are so lucky. As a foreigner at Korea HQ, you may be thrust into a role which gives you a chance to see the world through business trips. 3 free meals a day at the cafeteria and free shuttle bus transportation to/from work.
cons: Initiatives and executives come and go at the blink of an eye. Poorly-defined roles & responsibilities for most employees -- this ambiguity causes a lot of project overlap among groups and you often find 2 groups working on the same project simultaneously, unbeknownst to each other. Excessive politicking. Little collaboration between groups. Still a very strong Korean hierarchy and junior level employees don't take personal initiative or accept accountability. Important meetings are held in Korean language and as a foreigner you get left out -- unless you have somehow mastered the language on your own time as Samsung does not provide Korean classes for its foreign employees (you do receive a budget for education but no clear way to use this effectively while working a full-time job). No flexibility at all to work outside the office, and your hours are tracked; i.e. you must sit at your desk for 9 hours/day even if you have nothing to do!

cons:
Work life balance is challenging, however if work is enjoyable and fulfilling the balance is not so important.
Too much focus on technical skills rather than leadership, managing change and communication. This leads to frustration and lack of understanding by employees of their roles and responbibilities and how what they do impacts the organisation. 
Too much top-down Korean management style, unfortunately this also applies to many local managers who use this as an excuse not to give feedback or support.
Lack of awareness of skill gaps, managers don't get feedback on leadership capability only revenue i.e. as long as they sell/market/manage products well they will be seen as high performers irrespective of how they treat the people around them. They generally get promoted.

review_title: Interesting place to work for indeed
pros: Samsung Electronics is a truly a gigantic corporate empire. You get to dog food almost all aspects of your economic life. Company is doing great and spirit is high. Benefits are okay. Great newly built buildings, gym, cafeteria, etc.. Competitive pay in local standards. Well-received by general public. (Company takes up 20~25% of S.Korean stock market in terms of market cap., and also 20~30% of total Korean exports) Senior management is composed of some of the best people in the business who are great at bringing in new bread winning deals and setting the right course for the company.
cons: Bureaucracy is near government-level. HR too deeply involved in gauging engineering talents and reviews, so much so that smart, creative, but non-conforming engineers are not treated well. HR knows jack about what engineering does yet they are given power to evaluate? Engineering managers don't have any real power in terms of controlling manpower because of the HR intervention. Performance review is corrupt to the point it is virtually irrelevant. Every year a set percentage of employees are given highest/lowest grade in evaluations, but engineering managers work around it by having their team members take turns taking the lowest grade, completely regardless of their performance. Lots of freeloaders who're there just to pretend to be working and kill time. Too much emphasis on "prettifying" documentations. Why must you use PPT in everything? Encouraging employees to quit smoking was great idea; forcing them to take blood tests for nicotine and checking CCTV / building entry logs to identify smokers and penalize them in performance reviews, not so great and might be illegal in first world countries.

pros: Employees are proud to work in Samsung as it is one of top 10 global brands. We get regular salary, and diverse benefits on top. Working environment is dynamic - it is never boring. International colleagues; possibility to travel to other Samsung subsidiaries for training. Possibility to learn a lot about everything. Existing awarding system for employees. Most employees are visionaries, with strong will and dedication to their work and to the success of the company. Many people from outside envy those who work in Samsung and dream of getting a job there.
cons: Stressful working environment, unrealistic targets set by management, unhealthy competition between employees. Too many changes - of hierarchy, of internal procedures, high employee fluctuation, difficult to keep up. Work overload, working overtime is expected from everybody. Bad work/life balance. There is a lot of guessing without exact instructions from management due to their lack of experience and know-how. Salaries are not fair and equal for people in same/similar positions. No predefined career path for employees, slow promotion system. Too many young employees without experience. Open space offices - no privacy, difficult when it comes to confidential business issues. Too many unneccessary, unproductive meetings. Too much reporting - often a waste of time. Too many internal programs in which employees work, often it is confusing. In theory a good idea for internal control and organisation, but difficult to handle in every-day practical work. Approvals by 3-8 people should be obtained for every single thing.

review_title: Great place for experience, but don't expect and real vertical momentum
pros:
This is a great place to grow experience with plenty of duties to fill. Everyone needs to be well-rounded, filling multiple roles, which tend to multiply over time. My job today is nothing like the job description when I was hired, which has led to an expanding portfolio to showcase of my design, video and multimedia works. My role keeps growing which is nice, since it tends to give better job security. 
Working in marketing is also nice with the many interesting and fun programs and sponsorships we do. It's definitely something good to put on the resume having worked for Samsung.
cons: The opportunities for growth as far as promotion and actual recognition of increased duties has been next to nil. I have increased my duties ten fold since I started, yet make the same pay and have the same title when I started. Every time I add a new skill or service, it becomes part of my job requirements. Three years have passed and I am still considered 'contract', lacking any benefits. The frustration mounts when new hires are brought on as 'full time' from the start. Being expected to help them with deliverables to fulfill their annual bonus only adds to the sense of unfairness. Although I am appreciative for working here, too many things make me wonder if there are better opportunities.

pros: I rate Samsung very high because I like this company and the effort they do. I had very good relation with the HQ, the VP and the directors.
cons:
I read in previous reviews that the atmosphere at Samsung Staines is very toxic. Some have said that they had bad experience working with people of Indian origins. 

I don't generalize, but my experience working in a team where the majority were of Indian origin was not good. I felt there is a lot favoritism and pressure. Hindi is the main language (we're living in England). They use their mother tongue as a language of exchange, so that you don't understand. You feel you're there, but outside what is happening. A complete dilemma.

The team lead is very rude and offensive. I had to report him to the HR, but I did not do. I don't like to report. I joined the company to work and promote the business.

Finally, a European R&D should receive people with a research background. People who have validated their degree in Europe or got an equivalent of the degree they hold.

There is a retention bonus policy, wherein one has to work for atleast 3 years to get the assured package, otherwise have to return the retention bonus part of the salary, which is almost 30% of the total annual compensation .

Extremely tight security. Cant take laptops out of office. Cant bring anything like usb, ipod, etc inside. Hence, can't work from home.

No wifi in office. Even the ethernet speed is very poor(~10 Mbps)

Lot of disparity in compensation and general behavior between IITians and non-ITians.

Work life balance in most of the teams is poor. 

HQ in Korea makes all the decisions. No ownership of any project, except some really bad projects who don't have any commercial value.

Some teams are called to work in weekends, while other teams hardly work half the time they are in office.

No recreation in office, other than a Foosball table and two tt tables for ~5k employees .

review_title: A lot of potential going down the drain
pros: Samsung has great innovative products and the team I was in was great and supportive. Pay and benefits were good such as fuel card, car allowance, corporate card etc.
cons:
Greater Samsung business does not understand Enterprise business
No Work life balance - expect to work 60-80 hours every week if you don't want to fall behind
Customers are affected because the consumer processes are forced on an enterprise business and they don't work the same way.
Higher priority on internal reports, meetings and training even to the point of having field sales people cancel customer meetings in favour of internal requirements
Flexible working policy is frowned upon - must be in the office if not at customer meetings  even though the company is selling mobility as their main go to market in Enterprise space. 
Internal policies and approval chains put needless overheads and inefficiencies on the business. Eg not allowed network connection through ethernet on other floors in office, only your own. Must apply to take laptop out of office every couple of months.

review_title: Best Korean company, can be hard for expats.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Suwŏn, Kyonggi
pros: Lots of different projects across the company to work on. Samsung owns more different businesses that you can imaging. If you find the project you are interested in, you can have opportunity to work with world-wide data and implement this project in millions devices across the world. Great benefit package for expats - flat provided, free meals, free transport etc.
cons: Samsung does not have any clear plan to grow and overcome competitors, so time to time you meet illogical business decisions. Lot's of respect to all kind of formalities: if you are older and have some certificates you will likely to always have better performance grades, and your actual performance does not really counts. HQ is company for koreans - all good learning opportunities and resources are provided on Korean only. Work emails are in Korean. If you don't know Korean you will probably know all the news in the very last moment. If you project looks not important to VP you can have no work tasks for half year and that's ok. Situation IS changing to better side, but far from perfect. So I can recommend Samsung only to mentally stable people - still, work is interesting and living in Korea is great.

job_title: Sales Assistant Manager in Commerce, CA
pros: Benefits are good- health, dental, vision, subsidized lunches, gym membership, 401k, and education. Global network and a good name to have company pride.
cons: Unless you know the Korean language, you can't get far within the company. HQ folks look down on you and rotational staffs don't care about you.  Environment was bad- low morale where EVERYONE wanted to quit the company. Although you may be hired under a certain position, you are expected to do many many things outside your position. It's good to get diverse experience, but you will never become good at any one thing.  Compensation was so low that it made me feel like I wasn't worth much despite all the hard work I put in. There was lack of appreciation and too many comments that were borderline harassment- "your arms are thick", "it looks like you need to lose a few more pounds", etc.... Although I learned a lot during my time there, I am glad to have left.

review_title: Wasting your professional Life.No motive to work.Big "Headache" every time.
pros:
1. Free Food.
2. Free AC Transport.
3. Money if you are getting good ratings.
cons:
I found many and few are as below - 
1. No work Culture.

2. Now a days new trend is "Test". They have many level of test and if you are not able to clear those test you might loss your job and test is not relevant to your work at all.Test is the level of like you are working for "NASA".

3.Origin of politics is rating - They have annual rating to employees from 1 to 5.(1 is best 5 is worst).For that they need to maintain Bell curve.Which results around 25% employee will fall in to rating 4 & 5. End result is No hike for those employee and they have maximum 2~4 months to get a new job as HR will start asking to them to search a new Job they will thrown out of projects.Though if you get 1 or 2 rating no issue at all.
If you are a new joiner then you have fair enough chances to get 4 & 5 rating.

4. No work life balance you have to complete 8.30 hours in side office barrier not doing this will effect your salary.So if you have work or not you have to be there in office.

5. Management is not so effective(Both Indian and Korean).

6.  No new technologies to work on.

7. Current environment of company is - Most of trying to get new job outside or preparing for Test.No one is interested in work.

8. Engineers have least values.

9. Most of employees are working here due to NCR as they have home near by apart from that no reasons. Including mine also.

cons:
Very rigid Korean control of key decisions and processes, yet can be incredibly chaotic and disorganised at the coal face. Needs better local control and a wider range of input.
Obsessive IT systems security and rigid approval processes are both obstructive to day to day activities.
Tends to produce employees of extremes - either Samsung-worshipping workaholics who you expect to find dead at their desks one morning, or people who use the vast structure and ever-present disorganisation to actually do very little. Very few "normal" people who work hard, and deliver on commitments, but go home on time and don't live and breathe the job.

review_title: IF YOU ARE AN EXPAT EXPERIENCED HIRE RUN AWAY
pros:
-Salary only if you can negotiate the moon and stand firm on your numbers
-The gym in Suwon R5 is amazing
-Cafeteria food (while it can get sorta boring) is actually quite good.  well for free food.
cons: Possibly the worst decision ever in my professional career.  I was an experienced expat hire having previously worked for other top companies (APPLE, MSFT, GOOGLE...take your pick).  Worked for Samsung Mobile marketing...you know the group that puts those dog and pony shows with Korean executives speaking with their poorly spoken English. This place will absolutely rot your soul.  You will wonder every day of your stringent 1.5 or 2 year contract, what you are doing there; why you are there; and how to kill time.  Every minute of your mandatory 10 hour days (yes, they track your hours and you will get an incomplete if you do not put in your full 10 hours).  Yes, you have to go through an airport security system and put your bags through an X-ray machine.  i could go on and on.  But the most important point is that as a professional hire, you will regress.  While you are rotting away in Suwon with absolutely nothing to do, your colleagues back home will be moving up progressively or have worked on something amazing. For more details please check out a book called Noonchi:  The Appearance of Working in a South Korean Chaebol for the painful details.  Yes, a former employee wrote a tell-all expose because it was the only way to keep sane.

review_title: Very hard working and good compensation but mono hierarchial decision-making
job_title: Senior Sales Manager in Suwŏn, Kyonggi
pros: You can learn a lot of well organized working process related with (overseas) sales and marketing inclduing SCM. This company is well equipped with management system (global ERP) over the world, which is kingpin of the company's on-going innovation. If you're not a grumbler at a bunch of work imposed by that system, you can have a insight on how the work flows very soon - including the work of mid management level - despite of your very short work experience. I bet this is the unique systematic culture that hardly acquire in other enterprise. Recently the company started to focus on work-life balance including drepression clinic for the employees - the company maybe can be free of infamous hard-working organization soon. But I don't believe that the life of upper sr. manager level would not change easily because change does not come to the people who are accustomed to old-fashioned life-work-sytle.
cons: Every one in charge of sales has to bear the pressure of KPI (key performance indicator) established as a part of annual/quarterly management plan, moreover weekly(monthly) sales accuracy rate is a the most critical one for sales persons - so called "demand plan" result. As overall working process is controlled systematically, in many cases employees seems to feel a sensation that they are a kind of tools for the company goal, which discourage and make them boring at work.

review_title: PLEASE address morale of the field team
pros: Used to be a great job with a lot flexibility. Those days are toast.
cons: I don't know who is dictating the schedule of the field team, but it's gone from bad to worse. Used to be a Mon-Fri job. It was awesome. Now, who the eff knows. We get sent out a schedule a week before it starts for the month. Working company holidays, 8 DAYS IN A ROW over Thanksgiving...for no other reason than this greedy company trying to push a few more boxes. The team is miserable, doesn't have 2 days off in a row...I could go on. This has gone from a territory management role to a retail micromanaged position. Don't you dare have more than 3 pieces of swag on your table during table days, or try to spend time with your family on weekends. I'm sure after S10 launches, they will see a TON of turnover. All the good ones are leaving and upper management doesn't give a damn. Oh, and you will only be promoted if you came from the best buy side....a failing program.

pros: You get a paycheck, 10 days of PTO (for the entire year), No vacation time, health benefits are good
cons: This is the most unethical, unorganized, and unstable place I have ever worked at. Be prepared to work six days(12 hours)/week. This is great if you are an hourly associate since you will receive overtime pay. However, if you are salary do not expect to receive overtime pay.  Supervisors are paid $12.50/hr on Saturdays.  That's right $12.50/hr on Saturdays. We make less than  hourly associates on Saturdays. Area Leaders make more than supervisors with all the overtime we are working. Some Area Leaders base pay is over $20/hr and $30+ with overtime. Supervisors are well underpaid (salary range $49k-$70k+) when considering the amount of time spent in the plant as well as the workload.  There is a major disconnect between HR and supervisors on the production floor.  We are treated like incompetent children by HR. They do not take the time to establish a professional relationship with us. The communication between HR and management here is extremely poor. There is no chain of command in the way information is delivered.  Quite often the associates will receive pertinent information before the supervisor. This place is also not a safe place to work at.  Safety is not a top concern to upper management. The turnover rate is alarming high. We lost at least 20 salary employees within the month of July alone. I have been working at SEHA for less than six months and I am leaving as soon as I find another job.

pros: Lots of responsibility on offer; if you wanna do something, change something - go ahead.  You can really impress and get noticed no matter what grade you're at. Finally, Kimchi in the employee resturant is an aquired taste, especially the green version :-)

review_title: Great internship, for potentially dreadful job if you don't speak Korean and cannot communicate!
job_title: Intern (Advanced Audio R&D Group, Visual Display Division in Suwŏn, Kyonggi
pros:
I did a 9 week internship in the group working on audio path hardware and software for TVs.

Pros:
1. Interns are treated well - pay is good, accommodation was amazing, and we were not expected to work the standard long hours.
2. Because I had some previous experience I got assigned meaningful (but not in anyway useful for the company) tasks and actually learned some technical skills.
3. Other interns were really smart and good people to hang out with
4. Free Korean classes - opportunity to pick up basic Korean
5. Opportunity to travel around Korea afterwards
6. Insight into corporate culture of a massive "eastern" company
cons:
1. Big one - language barrier. A lot of employees are either not good at English or are reluctant to use it. If you can't speak the language (Korean), you can hardy do your best!
2. Long working hours. A lot of people choose to/have to work from around 8 till around 9-11. Its very widespread and a lot of people seem to prefer work to family.
3. Lack of social like - 1 and 2 combined means that its hard to make Korean friends (language barrier) and little time to do anything outside work.

pros:
It is one of the largest handset makers in the world and they do make some good products.
It certainly is a plus on your resume.
You can meet and work with some smart people in Korea.
cons:
The upper management know very little about software.
There is lot of politics and there are many incompetent managers.
The project schedule is always hard to achieve thus making you work long hours, weekends and holidays.
You do not have a personal life since you basically live at the company.
If you are a foreign employee working in Korea, you won't get a lot of action even if you speak good Korean.
The basic salary is below average.
You get paid above average if your division makes lots of profit. (e.g. Mobile Communication Division) You can get up to 50% of your annual salary.
If your division do not profit, you will be very disappointed.
(If they pay you a lot, then there is certainly a good reason behind it.)
Once in a while you can find people die possibly due to pressure, stress and too much work.
The company tries to keep things very quiet about this.
They make money ripping off small Korean companies and part suppliers.
They won't ever make something innovative like the iPhone.

review_title: OK, but must be Korean to have any control
pros: Good technology, good learning chances.  Good benefits IF you end up as regular employee instead of contracting.  Great if you speak Korean.  Diverse culture.
cons:
Most positions are contracting through other agencies, lots of cheap Visa labor.  A Korean's word is worth that of 10 Americans - so don't even try to persuade things to go the way you think is right.  

Crazy level of approvals required for anything.  Without a Doctor's note you cannot get a non-standard keyboard or mouse - and just forget about wireless.  Must get approval every year for every exception, like being allowed to use USB ports (and it might take a week, or a month to go through the system).  

If you don't force the work-life balance, they will walk all over you. Some managers allow flexibility, but it's rare.  

Goal seems to be: Be #2 - copy innovation rather than create it, but then try to be more profitable with it.  Works well, but not the best for the people.

review_title: Working in Samsung is good, but working in Korea is not recommendable
pros: Relatively good salary/remuleration/treatment comparing other Korean companies. The company is still not familiar with foreign workers, but changing fastly. It has several famous foreign executive people. Has more advanced, globalized management style and culture. Working in Samsung can give you further job opportunities IN KOREA.
cons: Life in Korea is kind of question mark. Seoul is fantastic city, which is really dynamic and convenient, however life in Seoul is very emulous. Koreans tend to focus more on work than family; they usually over work, and even drinking after work with team is considered as a part of work. In this point, Samsung is not an exception. Raising kids is difficult even for Koreans; you will see almost every parents pay huge money for additional/private education, since public education system is kind of disaster. (But for foreign workers, I think Samsung will take care of this.) Historically Korea is very homogenous, so sometimes you can see religious/cultural/racial discriminations; not in company but in your social life. Difference between Seoul area and other cities is big; other areas far from Seoul is quite bored. All culture, industry, conveniences is concentrated in Seoul area.

cons:
What an awful place to work. There is a serious lack of management - senior management is generally Korean and therefore there is a big language barrier. Majority of these managers have gained their positions due to their nationality and not their skills, qualifications or experience. You find yourself making most (if not all) of the big decisions on behalf of management. It really is the blind leading the blind. 

You will struggle to gain any recognition or growth unless you are Korean. 

It is a company that operates very much like a small business yet it is a multinational company?! There is no structure whatsoever. No building maintenance, guidelines, processes or training. Actually, you do get training, but on how to address Korean people (not how to use Samsung’s systems etc.)  - and that’s only if you are permanent! 

No ability to work from home - in fact you can’t even use a USB stick without permission from HQ. It really is an absurd place to work. 

Samsung’s staff turnover is shockingly high - for a reason! 

In my time there I never once had any discussions about future development, progression etc. It’s like you get a position and you’re stuck there for life.

pros:
Good People Nice Building,

Apart from that there is nothing else to say
cons:
Will never be appreciated this is a Korean company and unless your are a Korean you will be no one just a worthless number used for your local language skills nothing else. 

Koreans will ask lots of questions and explanations but will never share their thoughts and ideas with you. Even though you spent 15 minutes explaining something they don`t understand.  

They don`t respect our European culture its either their way or the highway. But we still have to do various Korean Culture Courses to understand theirs. They always give you the impression that you are never trusted in their company.  
 
Stay way clear if you want to grow within a company you will never move here unless you are laid off..

You are simply there to say yes sir and do as you told. 

Your family and friends will think you made it but in reality they don`t know that over time you will be afraid over your own shadow. Being a long time in a culture as this will do long term damage and break your confidence. Is that really success ?

pros:
Good salary
 onsite opportunity
Food coupons
Transport facility etc
cons:
worst work culture.
No trust on employees
Here you will be asked to work on any technology and there is no attention on domain building .
Management is worst be it resource management or project management. 
Here key to your success is not you excellence or dedication but your personal relationship with manager counts.
Koreans treat Indian employees as labours and your dedication is judged by the hours you stay in the office. Work life balance is no concern here.
If you stay here for 2 years you will mess up ur skills and become jack of all trades.
Hard outtimes so you have to stay at least 9 hours within office. 
Now a days another policy has started ie tests.. subjective questions with 100 % negative marking so no job security also .
If you have compulsion to stay in the NCR and can compromise with  all this .. then its your dream place .

review_title: Lack of logical process, internally focused, quantity trumps quality, obedience trumps talent, global talents' blackhole
pros: True global exposure, high brand value, financial strength, aggressive global expansion, decent expat count, acceptable expat welfare
cons:
- Internal process driven: project development is oriented by internal reporting and approval - NOT client and project needs
- Unsustainable growth strategy: (undisclosed)
- Top-down management: the top are decision makers regardless, management can be incompetent, overlapping R&R, misplaced talents
- Capabilities: mostly generalists, few specialists; teams are run by Korean managers who are promoted based on years of employment and connections - NOT by capabilities and performance
- Communication barrier: verbal communications and writings are practiced in Korean; English practice are done for "show"
- Promotion: seniority-based; years of employment trumps performance; evaluation system does not reflect on performance
- Salary: high among Korean firms, low compared internationally
- Working hour: 8am - 5pm on paper, 8am - 6:30pm on average; (mind you, most stay much longer)
- Corporate value and virtue: hyprocrisy may be the most suitable word. Values are on paper, practiced for show, generally lacking in true practice

pros: In thd center of Israel, near tbe train, good salary.
cons:
Most of the jobs are reuse, in the beginning very interpesting than more of the same.
Management doesn't care about the employees, present themselves as a family company buy are far away from it.
They present themselves as big company but act like a small startup. 
Before tapeout the management expect you to work 24/7 which is common in the industry but you spend many hours waiting for licenses.
They got order to close a group, the next day they fired the people with one month notice in the middle of August knowing that there is no way to found a job untill November (summer vacation and holidays).
One week before the decision this group start working on the most important project of Samsug Semi Conductor, one month before they finished working 24/7 on a other critical project.
The site manager didn't even fly to Korea to try to change the decision.
One week later they announced on company happening to the employees and there families during the notice period  and didn't invite the people that were laid off.
The meaning of closing this group (backend) is smallest project to the site.
The compensation isn't transparent, in the end of tbe year the human resource manager decide how much to give you without any critirias.
I recommend no one to go there since with this management I see no future to the site.

review_title: Interesting to try, but does not worth staying for too long time
pros:
Good chance to study Asian culture. 
Low taxes and social payments in Korea.
Good benefits (including free healthcare and housing).
Probably good for unexperienced engineers as a start, as the compensation and benefits are reasonable and often no special experience is required.
Even though Samsung is very Asian company (see downsides), they are trying hard to acquire western corporate culture, so the situation will, probably, become better.
If you endure Samsung, all other companies are piece-a-cake.
cons:
Even though English is official company language, the ability of significant portion of employees to speak it is close to nothing. 
Do not expect your colleagues to share information with you, unless they have no other options. 
There is no chance for non-Korean to become a project leader (except for the case when you are hired as one). 
Head of your group may expect you to work overtime even if there is nothing to do, just to show your loyalty to the company. 
Difference in salary (at the same position) depending on the nationality.
You may have a meeting to discuss problem of work and life balance. Starting at 8 pm. Really.

review_title: Working as Expat in Samsung Electronics HQ - Software R&D Center
pros:
+ Good benefits
+ Work-time is flexible and not too many hours
+ Probably one of the best office environments in the world (office space, infrastructure, restaurant gym)
cons:
- As foreigner you will be doing not much important work. Probably unimportant side tasks
- Endless analysis paralysis. You will probably end-up in an endless project proposal cycle. Samsung wants your ideas, but they don't want you to execute it. Your team leader will take your ideas and sell them as his own, you won't get credits for your ideas (That's probably just Korean work culture).
- Strong hierarchy culture. You are not supposed to give your ideas in meetings
- No english communication, you will be probably the only foreigner in a team that only communicates in Korean. Even in small meetings they will not switch to English. 
- You will be not involved in decision processes and most team members will avoid you due to issues with communication and working culture. It is kind of a hostile environment to foreigners (probably even to Koreans)
- You will make good money, but you will feel like sitting on the reserve bench with non important tasks assigned.

review_title: Know Your Risks When Joining Samsung
pros: Samsung practically owns the political and social institutions in Korea. This means having a relatively stable job that accords some semblance of taking pride, as long as you turn your head away from all that nonsense going on at Samsung. Because the company and its parent Samsung Group dominates all walks of life in Korea, one can choose to fool others and himself in believing that he is doing something genuinely important. When you tell others you work for Samsung as a Director, most people in Korea will respond with a display of respect+jealousy. No matter how desperate he may be on the inner conscience, one may keep up the fool's game.
cons: Samsung embodies some of the best and worst features of Korea's business culture. Hierarchy and favoritism, as well as nepotism run to the extreme. Senior management has deeply rotten sense of conscience, and don't feel ashamed. Silos between businesses mean one's peers from other BUs attack for the sake of discrediting competition for promotion. It is a food chain running from the Chairman down a long line of pecking order.

review_title: Samsung India software operations: Pathetic work place
pros:
1)Good work for some teams
2) Lots of freedom of work
cons:
1) Miserable work culture
2) Insecurity from top to bottom.You work good and you get screwed.
3) No training available.
4) Incompetent managers, no training, no morality. Samsung goes with perceptions and relations!
5) Timings 8.30a.m. You are late, it is half day.
     Fixed time for lunch. Fixed time for cafe!
6) Hypocracy is style of management. No reverse feedback. Manager can decide anything and say,
 You have to come on saturday because "I say So"
7)Developers are solely resposible for every thing. Lots of tension which in other companies managers resposibility. 
8) No appreciation! Lots of politics
9) No work from home, no trust from employer. They think you will steal the code.
10) Moral lectures with no ground. Pathetic leadership. MD comes late and forces every one to come at 8.30.
11)Spineless managers, schedule,pro-active communications, setting right expectations is crap thing in Samsung. Schedules are done on managers fantasy and developers are screwed till last penny
12) 90% people leave in bad terms and don't come back.Samsung culture makes sure that manager will screw you in resignation period.
In all miserable miserable work place. If you have worked in any of  US based MNC, don't ever come to samsung. Ever!

pros: i didn't find anything to praise
cons: bad management, Micro management, managers think you are a slave.

review_title: Worst mistake in my professional career : toxic place, very poor work environment, avoid at all cost.
pros: Leading consumer tech company, decent pay and benefits, but no more.
cons:
Top brass Koreans have absolutely no respect for locals, not even for their own people, they do not trust anyone, their disrespectful military style goes against moral and self-esteem, and creating employee fear is management number one job. Even if you are in an urgent need for a job, do not accept any offer, you will regret afterward, or you will get fired. Attrition is very high and not even justifies the need for a learning opportunity. Poor work-life balance, employees can't comment or speak, just obey, no autonomy to take any decision, just follow orders, Koreans just want robots working for them. HH RR department ignores local country labor laws, and they walk a very thin line while trying to comply with minimum standards, they are just an instrument of senior management to blackmail employees, who must get things done or get fired.
You have a long way to learn respect for your employees. I'm not writing this review to attack Samsung, neither expecting any kind of apology. I´m writing this review to advise anyone wishing to work for Samsung, not to make such a huge mistake as I did, my life was miserable there.

review_title: Good place for foundation building but not long term
pros:
1. Competitive Remuneration
2. Good Staff Benefits
3. Nice & Friendly Colleagues
4. Advanced Supply Chain System
5. Rich with Resources of Information like Data, Reseach, Numbers etc

Generally, I find the company is suitable for fresh grad and young people who would like to build their foundation in the corporate world as the company exercise performance based efficiency. Working style in Samsung would greatly disciplined and mold an individual to be analytical and efficient.
cons:
A company with strong remuneration and performance driven would come with a downside of many factors. One is expected to be as below;
1. Long Working Hours
2. System and Keyboard Warriors
3. Top Down demand, requirement and targets from Management
4. Stressful Environment 
5. Unrealistic Timeline
6. Strong Korean working style
7. No sense of Loyalty for the Brand

Samsung is a performance driven company, you must be measure by something to define excellent. There is no space for personal development in some skills or interpersonal development. Even the KPI and appraisal is based on how much you can do for the company and not what the company can do for you. Thus, 2 to 3 years max for experience gaining but not for long term.

job_title: Supply Chain Manager in Reading, England
pros: The only benefits are the pay is relatively good, pension, car, healthcare & dental plans.
cons: Nightmarish place to work.  Promises all but delivers nothing.  Extremely hierarchical Korean company that wants to be globalised but refuses to make any changes.  Internal communications & tools in 'Koreanglish'.  Endless pointless reporting, no one wants to make decisions on anything.  Local empowerment discouraged, never felt I could be fully responsible for my job - spent much of the time explaining what my job was to senior Korean staff with zero experience. Promotion based on age rather than ability.  Staff turnover highest I've ever seen in any company.  In the end, made to feel like a robot with no mind of your own.  Everyone in my team hated working here and were all looking for new jobs.

review_title: A great place to learn your craft...then move on.
pros:
- great benefits
- opportunity to work on exciting projects that are career defining
- employee discount on Samsung products
- great incentives when sales are up (but dependent on leadership at the time)
cons:
- pay is not equal to work load
- no equality in men and women
- women are largely non-existent on senior management team...token woman here and there
- promotions are largely based on political connections within the company
- work life balance is non-existent and hard on family life
- favoritism is rampant and if you are not 'in' with the senior executives, you can forget a promotion
- reviews are largely based on if you are 'tight' with your boss...ridiculous!

pros: It's a great place to contribute to unique innovation, with high potential of you work being literally in the hands of millions. Very interesting projects. Pretty fast development pace, a lot to learn.
cons:
Israeli subsidiary is a "foreign" body to the Korean headquarters, hence the main drawbacks. It's very difficult to get support or get responses from engineers or managers at HQ. You are often kept in the dark regarding your project status, it may be closed without any notice, or you may learn about requirement changes just before (or the day after) deadline. 
Generally there is a pressure to treat employees in the "Korean" way, meaning: everybody should be willing to work as much as necessary and put long hours to show they devotion to the company; travel abroad and stay there as long an necessary, etc. Local Israeli management may shield you from some of this pressure, or may not -- depends on the group you are in. 
There is quite a big flow of people leaving the company because of this work environment.

pros:
Samsung has a lot of budget to develop marketing campaigns and events. 
Great opportunity to work with the best agencies around the world. 
It's an excellent company to learn how to be flexible and learn that you can make things done in a really short period of time.
If you embrace projects, there are opportunities in all areas, because R&R it's not defined.
cons:
No autonomy to make decisions. There are too many useless and stupid processes that only  make employees lose time, instead of thinking in the strategical decisions. 
Deadlines are really tight and with the processes, generate more stress to make things done. Some Koreans don't speak english and don't understand local needs. 
No R&R defined. In order to take advantage of the company, it's important to embrace all projects that company offers.
Samsung has more directors and managers than analyst and interns and the processes are the same for everybody, so it makes people frustrated.
No life balance. No flexible hours. Koreans like to see people in their seats all the time.

pros:
* Good line/mid-management
* Very nice team - both highly professional and friendly
* Lots of really interesting and state-of-the-art system programming projects
cons:
* Low salaries (used to be competitive until recent drop of Russian currency)
* Inefficient, illogical and authoritarian management style of Korean partners (although this is partly compensated by good local management)
* Some employees are surprisingly incompetent (guess that's normal for a large company though)
* Company hires extremely (I mean _extremely_) professional guys and then give absolutely silly and boring work
* Projects get started and cancelled by Korean partners all of a sudden with all existing work and experience being sent to /dev/null (funny enough projects often get restarted from scratch by another team in 2-3 years); local management don't seem to have _any_ influence on these decisions
* Managers don't seem to have long-term strategy (probably caused by above)
* Most real decision making is done in HQ - Moscow office is just a pitiful outsource

pros:
Mobile devices is a very exciting category in terms of innovation, and competitive activity. Consumers are extremely engaged with their brands.

They pay extremely well and have two rounds of performance bonus in a year. Overall more cash oriented versus total benefits.
cons:
Culture needs a LOT of work. It's not behaving like a Global/multinational company. It's essentially a Korean company with a global footprint. That says a lot. Korean leaders are considered gods -- and behave as such.  Cross them once and you will be marked forever - i.e. subjective performance reviews, delays in promotion, limited exposure.

Furthermore, it's a very sales-oriented organisation at the core -- in contrast to being marketing-oriented as for other global consumer brand companies. That being said, classically-trained brand marketing professionals will not find fulfilment or recognition here as they are seen only as campaign execution drivers rather than drivers of overall brand and business strategy.

There's also no real Global Mobility program. You may get assigned to a 6month stint at HQ -- but it's very poorly planned, as you will practically do nothing, and understand nothing coz they all speak only Korean in meetings. Go figure.

review_title: Avoid SRUK if looking for career growth as permanent employee.
pros: Nice onsite restaurant, some benefits, work-life balance has improved dramatically because of less work being given by HQ.
cons:
Projects get canned every year and career path goes haywire. SRUK is just like a offshoring center with 1 year projects that need to be  negotiated with HQ every year. SRUK should not be called samsung and a separate entity. Contractors form a very high percentage of employees and they enjoy more clout, power, money and influence in the company. There are many contractors for a very long time spanning years. When projects are closed (there is at least one big project) then permies and contractors are treated the same, shown the door or placed in other projects, no difference at all, it feels like being contractor is better.
Very demoralizing environment as the business is not doing good. The future of SRUK is getting bleaker everyday but a number of people are living in oblivion.

job_title: PROCUREMENT Assistant MANAGER in Suwŏn, Kyonggi
pros:
In Korea, Samsung electronic is incredible company, so if you say I am employee of Samsung , people  treat you like VIP. For example , if you go to bank , you can have special offer of loan, thanks to employee of Samsung.  
They also give reasonable salary in Korea. this is important because in Korea, there are a lot of companies which don`t give reasonable salary to their employee.
cons: Work life balance is not great but Korean people don`t care about it. they just enjoy to stay in company . It seems to make people work hard but actually it is not. recently , they try to change this habit but it is very hard to change it because their directors have the habit and evaluate their team members by hours in office.

review_title: Depend on the team and place can be good or not
pros: Depending on the group/division your job can be funny and exciting. In general, the benefits are good but the salary sometimes are not competitive. In research teams, that I worked, you can participate in the most important congresses in the world. So, we have good chance to overseas travels.
cons: There are some teams that you will have few chances to learn or grow in your career. The evaluation performance process is horrible and forces managers to apply bad scores for good workers. It happens because the company wants only the best employees, but depending on the team size, the evaluation process might be a shot in the foot. Another bad aspect is the HR. In general, they are not transparent and many policies for employees are unclear.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Dallas, TX
pros:
Benefits are the best you can find out there (because you will need it after you are worked hard).

You get to play with new toys before they are released.

Many dedicated and great engineers to work with. Build up your network with great engineers for a while and leave when something better comes along.
 
You will always hear "Money is not a problem at Samsung".
cons:
The problems are just in all other places.

Poor planning, poor communication with HQ, poor work hours and work-life balance. Unclear expectations lead to a lot of rework and inefficiency. Inexperienced management that does not know how to properly plan a project. Massive reporting and micromanagement. Emergencies arise constantly that requires you to stay late for no good reason, e.g. create a demo for a visiting executive who just happens to be passing by to go somewhere else.

To properly gauge work-life balance, check the parking lot after hours or on weekends. Unfortunately, the parking lot here is full of cars after hours and on weekends.

Programmers are given only one monitor. Request for second monitor or more ergonomic workstation is always denied unless you get your doctor to declare you disabled.

This place also takes advantage of foreign workers who cannot easily transition to other jobs. And discriminates against Americans.

pros: For a job in Korea, the company takes good care in terms of foreigners in terms of salary, providing accommodation, three meals a day and additional perks.  You are somewhat treated as special in a Korean team, like a guess.  The problems are interesting and you will have opportunity to learn new things.
cons: You will experience severe isolation, you will likely be treated as a contractor and provided with absolute minimal context or background information.  Koreans often don't seem to want to hand you significant responsibility.  Due to hierarchy and fierce internal politics, managers often don't listen to feedback.   Opportunity for promotion into higher management is rare.   If you are employed as a senior, principal or master engineer, don't expect them to give you people to manage.  Unless for example you are an Indian and they are looking for someone to manage people in India.  The problems often have unrealistic goals and fairly few works make their way into products.

pros:
- One of the strongest global brand name
- Financial stability of the company 
- Job stability & security
- Koreans are very shy but very friendly once you get to know them
cons:
- Employees are made to work like bankers, except they are paid only 1/4th of what bankers get paid
- 12 hr is the baseline number of work hours;14 hrs face recommended if you are serious about your career at Samsung C&T; Be prepared for 16 hours/6 days if you really want your boss to like you
- Mandatory checkin into the office at 7:45 AM.  As such, the office schedule leaves no time personal commitments such as family and health
- Incentives are not aligned with performance.  Promotions solely based on number of years you've spent in the company (not on performance)
- Most power in the company is vested with the HR, not with your boss
- Unless you are an expat coming in at VP level, this place is a disaster for your career and personal life

review_title: All animals are created equal. Some are more Korean than others
pros: The people you sit with make or break your time there. I had GREAT companions in my corner of the building. Sharp, intelligent, warm, and everything a good office should have.
cons:
Contemplating a career here, or know someone who is? 
Point them to these reviews. Save yourself or that person, unless you dislike them!

Turnover is very high because training is non-existent.

Pay is low and likely to remain that way.

Samsung uses legacy technology to solve tomorrow's problems... except the deadline passed yesterday.

The WEBSITE CMS is a botched AEM implementation. HQ is stonewalling to 'save face'.

Bullying and harassment is rife in SERVICE division. 

Attempts to bring in Fair Work Australia have been foiled, most notably in 2014.
I can confidently say Pauline Hanson will devour a "halal snack pack" before that happens. 
 
Some companies dream of heading into space by 2020, like Virgin Galactic. And P0rnhub.
Samsung dreams of "Work Smart 2020 - Building a Creative Culture: Work Smart. Think Hard. Build Trust."
A closer description is: Hard Culture. Build Work. Group Think.
 
All this leads to an inevitable truth. We haemorrhage talent.

If you are starting your career, don't do it here if you have options.

review_title: face paced challenging jobs with good salaries
pros: Samsung offers fast paced challenging jobs all the time. I'm working for Samsung for about 10 years now and haven't had much time to look around for other jobs in the market. Management decisions are quickly made with proper background checks and numerous scenario analysis; I can say this is one of the reasons people who leave the company come back to Samsung.. a lot of people say they feel things are actually happening in this company and once they get used to this kind of working method, they get easily bored elsewhere.
cons: demanding job. switching off your brain after work might not be possible. it all depends on what you do in the company but jobs in samsung generally requires quite a bit of thinking, and you could easily find yourself staying late at work because the job is quite demanding. You also need to be stress resistent and open minded for Korean culture in the company (focus on efficiency, respect for seniority, emphasis on taking responsibility)

review_title: Managers could learn a thing or two
pros: The benefits are alright, good health insurance and access to Bookster. Salaries are on the market, too, though they could be better (and I am talking here about the Shared Services Center)
cons:
Outdated technology - got a used laptop that was pretty slow and ran on Win 7 (yes, in 2018). Got a used phone and was told that if I wanted headphones, they could disinfect a pair for me. 
The attitude of the managers was really bad - even with little experience, they were not open to make things (or themselves) better, even if the people they had on their teams had a lot more work experience. 
Micromanaging was the law and it cost a lot of people their efficiency and productiveness. 
Was promised a ‘flexible’ work schedule, but was actually forced to work 9 to 5 in the end.
Not doing overtime was frowned upon, even if you’d finished your duties for the day. 
Hiring overqualified people for the wrong jobs - or promising things in the interviews that are not happening.
Not allowing workers to move between teams if that is what they want.

pros:
Good benefits.  
If you're lucky, you'll have a good supervisor or manager who will protect you from all the negativities in the company.
cons:
No room to move up.  All the higher positions are given to Korean expats.
Can't participate in some meetings as they are in Korean.
Long work hours.  More than 8 hours of work each day (around 10 to 12 hours of work) and they expect you to finish everything every day but they will question you if you apply for OT too much and then be blamed if you fall behind.  So you end up working extra hours for free if you want to catch up with work.
Orientation talks about how Samsung Values its people and its corporate responsibility.  But reality is different.  There are managers/executives that shout and yell at employees as if we were in the Middle Ages.  And even if the employees complain to HR, the company does not do anything about it as they would rather keep the executive than the lowly employee.  Thus, good employees just give up and either stay and be miserable,  or resign to preserve their health, or find work with another company.

pros: You have a job and get paid twice a month
cons: You are micromanaged the entire time you are there.  The new Brokerage management is very over bearing and likes to do everything themselves, must have 100% control at all times.  There are no SOP's in place, just however they decide to do it and beat you over the head with it.  By this I mean extreme micromanaging to the point they count how many times you have to use the restroom.  Most extreme case of mistrust I have ever encountered in my career.  Asians need only apply this is truly all they want working for them.

review_title: Toxic environment, worst place to work
pros: Free coffee? Honestly not much.
cons:
- Directors will steal your work to make themselves look good to their VPs
- The pay is garbage - way below industry rate
- HR is completely incompetent to handle any situation - mostly focuses on events and stupid perks like cheap toys imported from China with the Samsung logo slapped on it 
- Managers will undermine you
- Employees gossip non-stop
- Very low productivity 
- Korean top-down management 
- No communication skills in anyone
- If you're female, you'll get sexually harassed at work at least twice a year
- Managers will manipulate you undermine you 
- Managers hire pretty girls for 'culture fit' to improve office morale, meanwhile demoralizing all the engineers who worked hard to get their jobs
- Everyone has a weak skill set with no product knowledge 
- Majority of employees have a drinking problem
- No stocks/shares offered
- Everyone is looking for a new job/interviewing
- The nicest people in the company are the security guards and janitors 
- Constant layoffs 
- 15% churn every year 
- HR doesn't care enough about recruiting events so they send engineers to attend them 
- Only focuses on very low impact projects like building websites, no innovation 
- No promotion opportunities
